","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T02:54:41.866Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":23.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495099,"topic_slug":"elevator-keeps-moving-to-same-spot","display_username":"Layton","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":70335,"username":"AegisNova","name":"Josh","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aegisnova/{size}/265035_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64705,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-keeps-moving-to-same-spot/495099/3","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3553757,"name":"Brian","username":"brian1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/50afbb/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T05:06:34.466Z","cooked":"

An elevator is under a constant downward acceleration due to gravity, and a PID controller’s output will get smaller as the elevator gets closer to it’s setpoint. Eventually, a bit below the setpoint, the PID controller’s upward output will balance out gravity. So, if the setpoint was 25, the elevator could get stuck at 24.25. To fix this, you could add a constant voltage to counteract gravity (kG). For example, with a kG of 0.5, you could replace the calls to setReference in ElevatorSubsystem with:

m_elevatorController.setReference(Setpoint, ControlType.kMAXMotionPositionControl, ClosedLoopSlot.kSlot0, 0.5);

You can tune kG by running the motors at different voltages and seeing what holds it in place.

To check if this is the problem before trying to fix it, you could try adding a small kI gain, and seeing if the elevator eventually gets to it’s setpoint.

Correct me if I’m wrong but could we also just tune our pid we have set up for the elevator

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T12:23:46.730Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":22.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495099,"topic_slug":"elevator-keeps-moving-to-same-spot","display_username":"Layton","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":73712,"username":"brian1","name":"Brian","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/50afbb/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64705,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-keeps-moving-to-same-spot/495099/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3554456,"name":"Brian","username":"brian1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/50afbb/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T20:46:53.754Z","cooked":"

Sort of. Increasing P will reduce the error proportionally, but it won’t ever go away completely. Changing D won’t affect the height the elevator settles at. Increasing I will eventually make the elevator get to the right height, but it will take a long time to stop oscillating.

With P and I, the elevator might move similarly to this graph, where time is on the x axis and the height of the elevator is on the y axis.

Elevator controlled with P and I1732×606 36.2 KB

In this simulation, the elevator passes it’s setpoint at around 1 second, but doesn’t settle there until a bit past 2 seconds. With an increased I, the elevator does get to it’s setpoint, but overshoots it and takes a while for it to settle (integral windup). In some cases, I could also move the elevator to slightly below it’s setpoint, then approach the setpoint slowly.

By adding G, a constant voltage to counteract gravity, the elevator’s path would look similar to this:

Elevator controlled with P, D, and G1742×598 31.3 KB

The G cancels out gravity, so the PID controller no longer settles below the setpoint or overshoots it. In this simulation, the elevator controlled with PID and G settles at it’s setpoint in a little over 1 second, twice as fast as the elevator controlled only with PID.

For elevators, a well-tuned PID controller will move it to the setpoint, but it will be a lot slower than if there was an additional G to cancel out gravity.

There’s some more information about controlling elevators on the WPILib and CTRE docs:

  • When Do We Need Feedforward Control?
  • Gravity Feedforward
  • Elevator Feedforward
  • Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling
